facts.text: Appellant is the owner by purchase in 1945 of premises in Vile Parle, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the owner, by purchase in 1945, of certain premises situate in Vile Parle, Bombay. Under the predecessor-in- title of the appellant,

facts.text: Thirumal Rao Potdar was a tenant under the predecessor-in-title in respect of a room in those premises at monthly rent of Rs. 20 including water rate of Rs. 2.

anchor.surface_text: Under the predecessor-in- title of the appellant, was a tenant, named Thirumal Rao Potdar, in respect of a room in 1396 those premises, at a monthly rent of Rs. 20 including water

facts.text: After appellant's purchase, the tenant Thirumal Rao Potdar continued to hold the tenancy on the same terms.

anchor.surface_text: After the, appellaiits purchase, the tenant aforesaid companytinued to hold the tenancy on those very terms. The said premises used to enjoy the amenity

facts.text: The premises enjoyed water supply from a municipal tap.

anchor.surface_text: The said premises used to enjoy the amenity of water supply from a municipal tap. As the appellants predecessor-in -title had made default in payment

facts.text: Appellant's predecessor-in-title made default in payment of municipal taxes, leading to water supply cut off by the Municipality early in May 1947.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellants predecessor-in -title had made default in payment of municipal taxes, the water supply had been cut off by the Municipality early in May, 1947.

facts.text: After May 1947, tenants including Thirumal Rao used well water only from a neighbouring tenant.

anchor.surface_text: Since after that, the tenants including the said Thirumal Rao, had the use of well water only from a neigh- bouring tenant. Thirumal Rao died in or about

facts.text: Thirumal Rao died in or about the year 1950.

facts.text: First respondent, widow of Thirumal Rao, continued in occupation of the premises.

facts.text: First respondent continued to pay original rent plus annas 10 more by way of permitted increase, totaling Rs. 20-10-0 monthly.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the landlord the appellant-went on receiving the monthly rent of Rs. 20-10-0 from the first respondent without giving her the benefit of water supply

facts.text: In April 1954, first respondent informed Municipal authorities that water supply from municipal tap stopped since 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Nothing appears to have happened until April, 1954, when the first respondent brought it to the numberice of the Municipal authorities that the supply

facts.text: Municipality responded to first respondent's complaint by letter dated May 24, 1954, stating water connection could be restored on payment of Rs. 11-4-0 if owner's consent produced.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipality answered the first respondents companyplaint by a letter dated May 24, 1954, saying that the water companynection companyld be restored on payment

facts.text: Before receiving Municipality's letter, first respondent had a letter sent to appellant through pleader demanding refund of Rs. 72 for water charges at Rs. 2 per month for three years after tenancy mutation.

anchor.surface_text: Before receiving this answer from the Municipality, the tenant got a letter written to the appellant, through a pleader, asking him to refund Rs. 72 being the amount

facts.text: Letter to appellant stated water supply withheld by landlord by allowing Municipality to disconnect for non-payment of dues.

anchor.surface_text: the amount charged for water supply at Rs. 2 per month, which was included in the total rent aforesaid for three years after the tenancy had been mutated

facts.text: Letter demanded appellant restore water connection, threatening prosecution under s.24 of the Act if failed.

anchor.surface_text: The letter also stated that the supply of water had been withheld by the landlord by allowing the Municipality to disconnect the water companynection for

facts.text: Appellant refused or neglected to restore water connection.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellant had refused or neglected to have the water companynection restored, the tenant filed a petition of companyplaint on June 14, 1954,

facts.text: First respondent filed complaint on June 14, 1954 for prosecution of appellant under s.24 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: the tenant filed a petition of companyplaint on June 14, 1954, for the prosecution of the appellant under s. 24 of the Act. The appellant was companyvicted.

facts.text: Appellant convicted by 7th Presidency Magistrate, Dadar, on March 24, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was companyvicted. after a trial by the 7th Presidency Magistrate, Dadar, by his judgment and order dated March 24, 1955. He was sentenced

facts.text: Appellant sentenced to one day's simple imprisonment and fine of Rs. 150, in default one month's simple imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: by his judgment and order dated March 24, 1955. He was sentenced to undergo one days simple imprisonment, and to pay a fine of Rs. 150, and in default

facts.text: Appellant filed revision in Bombay High Court against conviction and sentence, summarily rejected on April 22, 1955 by single judge.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved the High Court of Bombay in revision against the order of companyviction and sentence aforesaid. The matter was heard by a judge sitting singly,

facts.text: Bombay High Court Division Bench refused certificate for appeal to Supreme Court on May 16, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: who summarily rejected the application by an order dated April 22, 1955. The appellant moved the High Court for a certificate that this was a fit case

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on October 10, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: which was refused by a Division Bench on May 16, 1955. Thereafter, the appellant moved this Court for special leave which was granted on October 10, 1955.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 24, Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947
concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibits landlord from cutting off or withholding essential supply or service enjoyed by tenant without just or sufficient cause; provides remedies and penalties.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation I.-In this section essential supply or service includes supply of water, electricity, lights in passages and on staircases, lifts and conservancy or sanitary service.

concepts.interpretation: Supply of tap water is an essential supply.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: n  1  shall, on companyviction, be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three

concepts.unlisted_label: Explanation I to Section 24, Bombay Rents Act 1947
concepts.unlisted_description: Defines essential supply or service to include water supply.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation II.-For the purposes of this section, withholding any essential supply or service shall include acts or omissions attributable to the landlord on account of which the essential supply or service is cut off by the local authority or any other competent authority.

concepts.interpretation: Landlord's omission to pay fee and restore municipal water connection after cut-off by local authority constitutes withholding attributable to landlord.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: other hand, the section were companystrued in the sense that the supply should have been enjoyed at some time in the remote past, that is, before the

concepts.unlisted_label: Explanation II to Section 24, Bombay Rents Act 1947
concepts.unlisted_description: Withholding includes acts/omissions attributable to landlord causing cut-off by local authority.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation II was inserted by s. 16  2  of the Amending Act, namely, Bombay Act 61 of 1953, and the explanation 1, as it now stands, was the only explanation before the amending Act was passed.

concepts.unlisted_description: Amends Section 24 of Bombay Rents Act 1947 by inserting Explanation II.

issues.text: The only question for determination in this appeal, is whether an offence punishable under s. 24(4) of the Bombay Rents Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act LVII of 1947 hereinafter referred to as the Act, has been brought home to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The only question for determination in this appeal, is whether an offence punishable under s. 24 1  4  of the Bombay Rents Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act LVII of 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act , has

issues.text: The most important question which we have to determine in this appeal, is whether the constituent elements of an offence under s. 24(1), have been made out on the facts found in this case.

anchor.surface_text: The most important question which we have to determine in this appeal, is whether the constituent elements of an offence under s. 24 1 , have been made out on the facts found in this case.

issues.text: In order to attract the provisions of that section, it is also necessary that the second ingredient of the offence, should be there, namely, that that essential supply-tap water supply by the Municipality- should have been enjoyed by the tenant. Is it enough that this essential supply should have been enjoyed by the tenant at any past time, however remote, or that it should have been enjoyed at any time after the coming into effect of the Act?

holdings.text: The appellant's omission to restore the water connection is attributable to him under Explanation II to s.24 and constitutes withholding of essential supply.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, in so far as the appellant omitted to do so, such an omission is attributable to him within the meaning of explanation II which was inserted into the Act in 1953. There can, therefore, be no doubt that the appellant was continuing to withhold an essential supply within the meaning of s. 24, as it stood in 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expl II defines withholding to include landlord omissions causing cut-off by local authority; appellant could restore by paying Rs.11-4-0.

holdings.text: For s.24(1) to apply, the essential supply must have been enjoyed by the tenant after the Act came into force, not in remote past before the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are assuming for the purposes of this decision that the first respondent was the tenant at all material times. In our opinion, the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should -have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force. If, on the other hand, the section were construed in the sense that the supply should have been enjoyed at some time in the remote past, that is, before the Act was enforced,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual meaning requires post-Act availability; alternative pre-Act interpretation would create ex post facto penal liability violating Art.20(1).

holdings.text: 'Enjoyed by the tenant' requires actual availability and use of the supply, not merely a contractual right to it.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the argument is that the word enjoyed does not import physical use of the amenity in question, but 1400 the juridical aspect of it in the sense that the supply of the water, was one of the rights vested in the tenant. On this construction, if the tenant had, as in this case the first respondent had, the right to enjoy the supply of water, that would amount to her having enjoyed the supply, and, thus, both the requirements of s. 24 would be fulfilled. In our opinion, it would be straining the language of the section to say that enjoyed should mean had the right to enjoy .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strains ordinary language; Legislature would have used explicit words if so intended; contradicted by sub-s.(3) phrasing.

holdings.text: Sub-section (3) of s.24 imports recent enjoyment of the supply until it was cut off, not enjoyment in remote past.

anchor.surface_text: It speaks of the tenant has been in enjoyment of the essential supply or service and that it was cut off or withheld by the landlord which imports recent enjoyment until the supply was cut off, and not enjoyment in the remote past.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language of sub-s.(3) read with sub-s.(1) indicates proximate temporal enjoyment.

holdings.text: The provisions of s.24 must be construed as a whole to determine legislative intention.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the provisions of s. 24 have to be construed as a whole, in order to find out the true intention of the Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-s.(2) applies only on contravention of sub-s.(1); sub-ss.(2) and (3) interconnected with sub-s.(1).

holdings.text: Penal provisions of s.24 restricting landlord freedom must be strictly construed according to words used, without extension.

anchor.surface_text: Such remedies which are inroads upon the landlords freedom of action, have to be construed strictly in accordance with the words actually used by the Legislature, and they cannot be given an extended meaning.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exceptional temporary remedies; interpret narrowly as inroads on common law rights.

holdings.text: No offence under s.24(1) or (4) brought home to appellant as constituent elements not satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, in so far as the appellant omitted to do so, such an omission is attributable to him within the meaning of explanation II which was inserted into the Act in 1953. There can, therefore, be no doubt that the appellant was continuing to withhold an essential supply within the meaning of s. 24, as it stood in 1953.

In our opinion, the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should -have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force. If, on the other hand, the section were construed in the sense that the supply should have been enjoyed at some time in the remote past, that is, before the Act was enforced, the act of the landlord, when it was committed, may not have been penal but the same act would become penal on the coming into effect of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the argument is that the word enjoyed does not import physical use of the amenity in question, but 1400 the juridical aspect of it in the sense that the supply of the water, was one of the rights vested in the tenant. On this construction, if the tenant had, as in this case the first respondent had, the right to enjoy the supply of water, that would amount to her having enjoyed the supply, and, thus, both the requirements of s. 24 would be fulfilled. In our opinion, it would be straining the language of the section to say that enjoyed should mean had the right to enjoy .

In our opinion, the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should -have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force.
